summary: This is an email chain between FBI personnel discussing the status of digital evidence processing in the Epstein case. It details inventory counts from New York City and the US Virgin Islands, lists specific outstanding items requiring technical processing, and clarifies discrepancies in the evidence inventory for the US Attorney's Office.

persons.name: SSA - FBI New York
persons.context: The sender of the main email, inquiring about the status of digital evidence processing and the timeline for a file dump.

persons.name: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The author of the forwarded email, who attached a spreadsheet detailing the status of all digital evidence and clarified inventory discrepancies.

connections.person2: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Professional correspondence regarding the status of digital evidence processing for the Epstein case.

events.title: Forensic Examiner Provides Evidence Status
events.description: A Senior Forensic Examiner sends an email with an attached spreadsheet detailing the status of all digital evidence in the Epstein case, clarifying inventory discrepancies.
personsInvolved: NYO CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

events.title: SSA Follows Up on Evidence Processing
events.description: An FBI Supervisory Special Agent follows up on the evidence status, confirming counts and inquiring about the timeline for a file dump.

keyFacts: The document details 72 total digital evidence items: 32 from New York City and 40 from the US Virgin Islands.
Nine items were outstanding, including SSDs from a DVR, Macs needing a blacklight run, and RAID arrays needing rebuilding.

The correspondence clarifies significant evidence inventory discrepancies, noting items like duplicate hard drives and non-evidentiary media (software CDs, unprocessable voice recorders) were initially counted.
The email discusses an anticipated 'relativity file dump' expected to be complete in approximately 1.5 weeks.
